title: How to Make Origami Paper Claws

steps.title: Place the paper on a flat surface.
steps.content: Place the paper on a flat surface. Position the paper vertically (portrait). You can use any type of paper you have lying around the house. If you want sturdier claws, then use thicker paper.

steps.title: Fold the top right corner over and down.
steps.content: Fold the top right corner over and down. Align the fold to the paper's bottom. The left side of the sheet now has a point.

steps.title: Fold the point to the opposite corner.
steps.content: Fold the point to the opposite corner. It should look like a rectangle that is missing a corner. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Fold the diagonal edge at the top part down.
steps.content: Fold the diagonal edge at the top part down. Align the top edge to the diagonal edge. This should now be in the shape of a square. Position the paper with the right angle of the triangle pointing up, or away from you.

steps.title: Create a triangle.
steps.content: Create a triangle. Fold the square along the diagonal line. This should create a triangle.

steps.title: Fold the paper in half.
steps.content: Fold the paper in half. Imagine a vertical line dividing the triangle in half, from the point to the base, right down the middle. You're creating a right triangle. You may want to draw this line in pencil the first couple of times. Use a T-square to make sure the line down the middle is at a right angle to the base of the triangle. This fold is to form a crease that will be important for the following fold.

steps.title: Fold the left side into the crease.
steps.content: Fold the left side into the crease. Unfold the recently formed right triangle and fold the two edged side directly to the half-way line of the triangle. The fold's outer edge should be going straight down, perpendicular to the bottom and even extending below the bottom of your triangle.

steps.title: Repeat the previous fold two more times.
steps.content: Repeat the previous fold two more times. Fold the same side over itself again. You should be able to see the claw coming into form. [2] X Research source Be careful to line each fold with your imaginary pencil line. Make sure you keep each fold very tight and at the same angle. If the folds start to slant upwards, instead of staying aligned, the claw won't be as sturdy.

steps.title: Tuck the bottom flap into the end.
steps.content: Tuck the bottom flap into the end. You may need to open the hole for the flap up with your finger. Hold it so the opening is visible and easy to insert one flap.

steps.title: Open the smaller triangle in the middle of the folds.
steps.content: Open the smaller triangle in the middle of the folds. Simply stick your finger into the smaller triangle to open it up. This will look like a knuckle for the claw. [3] X Research source It may be a tight fit at first. The tighter the fit the more likely the claw will stay on your finger.

steps.title: Buy or construct origami paper.
steps.content: Buy or construct origami paper. To make origami paper, orient a standard sized paper (8.5x11) longways and fold a corner farthest to the opposite edge. Then cut off the excess part of the paper that wasn't covered by this fold. This will create a square. Sturdier paper will increase the durability.

steps.title: Fold the paper in half.
steps.content: Fold the paper in half. Imagine a line running from the top-left corner going to the bottom-right corner. Fold along this line to create a right triangle. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Fold the paper on the diagonal axis.
steps.content: Fold the paper on the diagonal axis. You are turning your right triangle into an scalene triangle. Make sure the crease is strong.

steps.title: Fold the paper on a diagonal axis, again.
steps.content: Fold the paper on a diagonal axis, again. The line that you are folding now will start from one corner, and will end in the middle of the other two corners. Continue to ensure that your creases are strong.

steps.title: Make a vertical valley fold.
steps.content: Make a vertical valley fold. Position the claw in front of you so the pointiest "nail" faces left. Imagine a line descending straight from the top tip to the bottom. Fold the smaller corner towards the "nail." Then unfold this fold. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Tuck the right tip into the pocket.
steps.content: Tuck the right tip into the pocket. By making the vertical valley fold, you've allowed a pocket to be formed. This is where your finger will go. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Place the paper on a flat surface.
steps.content: Place the paper on a flat surface. Position the paper horizontally. You can use any type of paper you have lying around the house. If you want sturdier claws, then use thicker paper.

steps.title: Fold the top left corner over and down.
steps.content: Fold the top left corner over and down. Align the fold to the paper's bottom. The left side of the sheet now has a point.

steps.title: Fold the two corners on the right side.
steps.content: Fold the two corners on the right side. Only fold these corners to the line of the previous fold. This will create two smaller triangles. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Fold the left point over.
steps.content: Fold the left point over. Imagine this right triangle without the other two triangles. Just fold the right tip to the opposite tip of the right triangle.

steps.title: Use the excess strip.
steps.content: Use the excess strip. Fold the excess strip with the two smaller triangles up onto the other triangle. This will form a triangle with this recent fold on top of it.

steps.title: Fold the paper in half.
steps.content: Fold the paper in half. Imagine a vertical line dividing the triangle in half, from the point to the base, right down the middle. You're creating a right triangle. This fold is to form a crease that will be important for the following fold.

steps.title: Fold the left side into the crease.
steps.content: Fold the left side into the crease. Unfold the recently formed right triangle and fold the two folded edges directly to the half-way line of the triangle. The fold's outer edge should be going straight down, perpendicular to the bottom and even extending below the bottom of your triangle.

steps.title: Repeat the previous fold two more times.
steps.content: Repeat the previous fold two more times. Fold the same side over itself again. You should be able to see the claw coming into form. [8] X Research source

steps.content: Tuck the bottom flap into the end. You may need to open the hole for the flap up with your finger. Hold it so the opening is visible and easy to insert one flap. [9] X Research source
